title: How to become a really good bass player? What steps should I follow - Quora

response.answer_text: Are you starting from scratch? If you are, then there are several answers below that may help you out. If you’re not and you’re already a decent bass player looking to get really good, I suggest the following. Join Talkbass.com. Many answers to many questions, including this one will be there.Listen to a lot of music. 99% listening and 1% playing, is what a teacher once told me. There will be many suggestions lists. Somewhere make sure you listen to Jaco Pastorius. Read his biography, watch a few videos. If you want to aspire, that’s where you aspire to go.Listen to a few pianists as well. Bill Evans is a good place to start. Listen to some sax players for phrasing.Bass players don’t have genres. Listen and play all genres.Follow a routine.Watch a few videos by Janek Gwizdala. He v-logs super regularlyInvest in gear. I would say, at the beginning of your career you should be spending 70% of your music related earnings in gear. This helps you have the best gear that you can afford, and not end up with too much expensive gear and no real need for it. Pedals and tone is very important and often overlooked. After your done with gear, invest in mentorshop sessions, books, concerts and online ed.Hope all of this helps. Enjoy!

We'll assume you have your first bass and amplifier.  You'll need personal instruction to learn how to dial these in.  To play the bass is fairly straight-forward from the novice level.  First, get a metronome; you can download one to your smart phone.  Practice tapping your left and then right foot to the even beat; do not get fancy with this.  Next, get tablature of the major scales and, using the metronome, practice maintaining an even beat on the different notes.  Use a heavy pick on the 'fat' side or your thumb or your first two fingers.  Listen to your favorite music and practice finding and playing evenly on notes that 'fit.'  Using the tablature, find the 1, 3 and 5 notes of the different scales and practice moving smoothly between  them.  You don't need an amp this but to have some sound most amps do have a headphone jack or you can acquire a 'SansAmp' and these allow you to play without threats from the neighbors or roomies. This will get you started.  If you're focused you can be minimally capable in about 20-hours.  YouTube has tons of instruction.  Have fun.

Learn the damn songs. Know them well enough that you know when the guitarist(s) has it wrong. Well enough that you can tell him what the chords on the recording are. Notice that’s not the “correct” chords. Saying that probably won’t fly at rehearsal. Devise parts other than what’s on the record that still fit and benefit the song. This is what takes you from regular bass player to really good bass player: improvisation. Soloing is not the only way musicians improvise. Figured bass in Baroque music requires the continuo player to improvise a full part based on a few symbols. Sound familiar?
